chapterTitle: Introduction to Valuation:The Time Value of Money

columns.text: In this question, we are required to calculate how long does it take to duplicate and quadruple your initial investment, with an interest rate of 6.1%.

To calculate this we need to use the formula of Present Value (PV) and rearrange it to obtain the value of time for each case.

$$\begin{aligned}

PV & = \dfrac{FV}{(1+r)^t}\\
\\
t &=\dfrac{ \ln \left( \dfrac{FV}{PV} \right)}{\ln(1+r)}

\end{aligned}$$

*Where:*

- FV is the future value 
- t are the times the rate is applied
- r is the rate applied

Next, we need to understand how these two scenarios can be computed. We know that the two cases are to duplicate and quadruple our investment, so we can compute it as such.

*First case:*
$$FV(x) = 2\cdot x$$

*Second case:*
$$FV(x) = 4\cdot x$$

*Where:* 
- x is the initial investment or PV

*First case:*

With that in mind, we can go ahead and give whichever value we to X and find our FV.

$$\begin{aligned}
FV(100) & = 100\cdot2\\
&= 200
\end{aligned}$$

So our **FV=200** and **PV=100** for the first case.

Next, we will calculate the t in this case.

$$\begin{aligned}
t &=\dfrac{ \ln \left( \dfrac{FV}{PV} \right)}{\ln(1+r)}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{ \ln \left( \dfrac{\$200}{\$100} \right)}{\ln(1+0.061)}\\[15pt]

&= \boxed{11.71}

\end{aligned}$$

It would take you **11.71 periods to duplicate** your money with an effective rate of 6.1%

*First case:*

For this case, we will repeat the process with the respective condition.

$$\begin{aligned}
FV(100) & = 100\cdot4\\
&= 400
\end{aligned}$$

So our **FV=400** and **PV=100** for the second case.

Finally, we will calculate the t in this case.

$$\begin{aligned}

t &=\dfrac{ \ln \left( \dfrac{FV}{PV} \right)}{\ln(1+r)}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{ \ln \left( \dfrac{\$400}{\$100} \right)}{\ln(1+0.061)}\\[15pt]

&= \boxed{23.41}

\end{aligned}$$

It would take you **23.41 periods to quadruple** your money with an effective rate of 6.1%
